title: journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/...

last_post.content:
People complain to algorithm makers about obvious social problems — and get frustrated when system makers say they can't possibly anticipate them.

Aside from corporate self-interest, I think this may result from differences in the level of analysis — algorithm makers imagine individual situations, while critics are imagining population trends.

For example, sexism & harassment has been a rampant pattern on reddit, but might still be hard to predict in individual cases

title: US universities are not succeeding in diversifying faculty - Nature Human Behaviour

last_post.content:
While marketers & algorithm designers care about making individual-level predictions, people concerned about the social impact of algorithms are often more interested in population-level predictions.

And collective behavior can be frustratingly stable. Consider, for example, the problem of inequality. Universities are highly complex systems, but my colleagues and I were able to model 99% of the variation in US faculty diversity, on average, with a very simple model

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41562-022-01495-4

title: World-first female crash test dummy could boost road safety

last_post.content:
Vehicle crash tests are only required to use dummies shaped like the avg male. But the avg female is shorter and lighter, with different torso, hip & pelvis shapes, resulting in a greater likelihood of whiplash injury, e.g.

Now researchers in Sweden, led by Dr Astrid Linder, have developed a female crash test dummy that reflects these anatomical differences, in hopes that future car safety will be assessed for all parts of the population.

title: The Surprising Story of the First Microprocessors

last_post.content:
@b0rk
Intel processors are little-endian because they copied the Datapoint 2200, which was a serial computer so it needed to be little endian.

In more detail, the Datapoint 2200 (1971) was built with TTL chips and used shift registers for memory, so it operated on one bit at a time. This forced it to be little endian, since arithmetic needs to start with the lowest bit.

Datapoint asked Intel and Texas Instruments about replacing the board of TTL chips with a single chip. Texas Instruments built the TMX 1795 and Intel slightly later built the Intel 8008. As copies of the Datapoint 2200, they were little endian. Intel improved the 8008 creating the 8080, 8086, x86, keeping the little endian architecture and many other Datapoint features.

I can give you lots of references. See my IEEE Spectrum article https://spectrum.ieee.org/the-surprising-story-of-the-first-microprocessors
Also see the book "Datapoint: The Lost Story of the Texans who Invented the Personal Computer."

title: Re: Meta and ActivityPub from Johannes Ernst on 2023-03-10 (public-swicg@w3.org from March 2023)

last_post.content:
@sevignes

#ActivityPub is an especially _weak standard_ where interoperability (the ability to talk back-and-forth with an AP system) is very ad-hoc and tends to be defined very heavily by the behavior of the largest and best-known implementations

So it is relatively straightforward for a company like Meta to throw resources at it, make changes that are incompatible, and then shift everyone to something custom down the road

See @J12t's https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-swicg/2023Mar/0067.html for how it can break down.

title: Index

last_post.content:
Hi friends, I have been working on a service to help get RSS feeds into mastodon, and it's more or less ready for prime time. It lives at:

https://feedsin.space/

Basically, you:

1) create an account by sending a message to @admin with the word "help", and clicking on the link you get back

2) specify the URL to a feed, and a username for the feed

3) your feed lives at ____@feedsin.space, and you can follow it like any other account in the fedi

Blog post here: https://muffinlabs.com/2023/03/09/feedsin-space/
